thread.title: Four Seasons George V becomes first hotel in Europe to house three Michelin-starred restaurants
thread.title_full: Four Seasons George V becomes first hotel in Europe to house three Michelin-starred restaurants

author: Rachel Cranshaw
title: Four Seasons George V becomes first hotel in Europe to house three Michelin-starred restaurants
text:
Articles Four Seasons George V becomes first hotel in Europe to house three Michelin-starred restaurants Le George, which opened in October 2015, offers relaxed dining in the form of light, contemporary Mediterranean-style cuisine Rachel Cranshaw , Content Editor - Hotels 9 February 2017 • 1:23pm 
P aris's Four Seasons Georges V has become the first hotel in Europe to have three Michelin-starred restaurants, after its Le George and L'Orangerie were awarded one Michelin star apiece. 
These were in addition to the three stars retained two years running by its signature Le Cinq . Le Cinq first earned its third Michelin star in 2016, with food as theatrical as its interiors 
L 'Oranger, which opened in May 2016, gained a Michelin star after just eight months. 
The menu takes its inspiration from nature and aims to complement the changing seasons, often using local garden produce. 
The restaurant overlooks the hotel's Marble Courtyard, and was also designed by Pierre-Yves Rochon. 
• The best hotels in Paris The menu at L'Orangerie takes its inspiration from nature 
L e George, which opened in October 2015, offers relaxed dining in the form of light, contemporary Mediterranean-style cuisine. 
Many dishes are designed for sharing, and the restaurant's interiors were designed by Pierre-Yves Rochon. 
• Read the full review: Four Seasons Georges V The seven-course 'Epicurean Escape' tasting menu at Le Cinqe features ‘Parisian-style’ gratinated onions Credit: BERNHARD_WINKELMANN 
L e Cinq first earned its third Michelin star in 2016, with food as theatrical as its interiors, including a seven-course 'Epicurean Escape' tasting menu. 
Our writer Jade Conroy listed courses of note when she ate there as: "chubby langoustine from Dublin Bay coated in mustard mayonnaise and served with a fortune cookie-shaped buckwheat pancake; a butter-smooth turbot served with mash and truffle foam (and an even more buttery Chardonnay) and – perhaps Le Squer’s signature dish, and one that shows off his technical acumen – ‘Parisian style’ gratinated onions."
